speaker: macDuff
dialog: What had he done, to make him fly the land?

speaker: ross
dialog: You must have patience, madam.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: He had none: His flight was madness: when our actions do not, Our fears do make us traitors.

speaker: ross
dialog: You know not Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Wisdom! to leave his wife, to leave his babes, His mansion and his titles in a place From whence himself does fly? He loves us not; He wants the natural touch: for the poor wren, The most diminutive of birds, will fight,

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Her young ones in her nest, against the owl.            All is the fear and nothing is the love;            As little is the wisdom, where the flight            So runs against all reason.

speaker: ross
dialog: My dearest coz, I pray you, school yourself: but for your husband,He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows The fits o' the season.

speaker: ross
dialog: I dare not speak much further;  But cruel are the times, when we are traitors   And do not know ourselves, when we hold rumour From what we fear, yet know not what we fear, But float upon a wild and violent sea

speaker: ross
dialog: Each way and move. I take my leave of you: Shall not be long but I'll be here again: Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upward To what they were before. My pretty cousin, Blessing upon you!

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Father'd he is, and yet he's fatherless.

speaker: ross
dialog: I am so much a fool, should I stay longer,            It would be my disgrace and your discomfort:            I take my leave at once.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Sirrah, your father's dead;            And what will you do now? How will you live?

speaker: son
dialog: As birds do, mother.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: What, with worms and flies?

speaker: son
dialog: With what I get, I mean; and so do they.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Poor bird! thou'ldst never fear the net nor lime,            The pitfall nor the gin.

speaker: son
dialog: Why should I, mother? Poor birds they are not set for.            My father is not dead, for all your saying.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Yes, he is dead; how wilt thou do for a father?

speaker: son
dialog: Nay, how will you do for a husband?

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Why, I can buy me twenty at any market.

speaker: son
dialog: Then you'll buy 'em to sell again.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Thou speak'st with all thy wit: and yet, i' faith,            With wit enough for thee.

speaker: son
dialog: Was my father a traitor, mother?

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Ay, that he was.

speaker: son
dialog: What is a traitor?

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Why, one that swears and lies.

speaker: son
dialog: And be all traitors that do so?

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Every one that does so is a traitor, and must be hanged.

speaker: son
dialog: And must they all be hanged that swear and lie?

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Every one.

speaker: son
dialog: Who must hang them?

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Why, the honest men.

speaker: son
dialog: Then the liars and swearers are fools, for there are liars and swearers enow to beat the honest men and hang up them.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Now, God help thee, poor monkey!            But how wilt thou do for a father?

speaker: son
dialog: If he were dead, you'ld weep for            him: if you would not, it were a good sign            that I should quickly have a new father.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Poor prattler, how thou talk'st!

speaker: messenger
dialog: Bless you, fair dame! I am not to you known, Though in your state of honour I am perfect. I doubt some danger does approach you nearly: If you will take a homely man's advice,

speaker: messenger
dialog: Be not found here; hence, with your little ones. To fright you thus, methinks, I am too savage; To do worse to you were fell cruelty, Which is too nigh your person. Heaven preserve you! I dare abide no longer.

speaker: macDuff
dialog: Whither should I fly? I have done no harm. But I remember now I am in this earthly world; where to do harm Is often laudable, to do good sometime Accounted dangerous folly: why then, alas, Do I put up that womanly defence, To say I have done no harm? What are these faces?

speaker: murderer
dialog: Where is your husband?

speaker: macDuff
dialog: I hope, in no place so unsanctified  Where such as thou mayst find him.

speaker: murderer
dialog: He's a traitor.

speaker: son
dialog: Thou liest, thou shag-hair'd villain!

speaker: murderer
dialog: What, you egg!            *Stabbing him*            Young fry of treachery!

speaker: son
dialog: He has kill'd me, mother: Run away, I pray you!
